summary: Official notification from the Federal Bureau of Prisons to two federal judges regarding the death of Jeffrey Epstein by apparent suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York on August 10, 2019. The letter states Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell, transported to a hospital, and pronounced dead. It notes pending autopsy and investigations by the FBI and DOJ Inspector General.

Reid Weingarten is listed as counsel for Jeffrey Epstein.
Both are listed as counsel for Jeffrey Epstein, indicating a professional legal association.
Both are federal judges addressed in the official notification regarding Epstein's death.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center around 6:30 a.m. from an apparent suicide. He was transported to a hospital and pronounced dead at 7:37 a.m.

events.title: Initiation of Investigations
events.description: The FBI began actively investigating the incident, and the Attorney General requested the DOJ Office of the Inspector General to also look into the matter.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), New York, New York 10007
New York Presbyterian-Lower Manhattan Hospital, New York, New York
Daniel Patrick Moynihan United States Courthouse, 500 Pearl Street, New York, New York 10007-1312
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died on August 10, 2019, at approximately 7:37 a.m. at a New York hospital after being found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center around 6:30 a.m.
The death is described as an 'apparent suicide' in the official notification from the Bureau of Prisons.
The cause of death was not immediately determined; an autopsy was pending at the time of the letter.
The FBI and the DOJ Office of the Inspector General were both investigating the incident.
The notification was sent to Chief Judge Colleen McMahon and Judge Richard M. Berman, with copies to Epstein's attorneys Martin Weinberg and Reid Weingarten.
